events.event_name: Copper Price Drop to Six-Week Low
events.description: Copper prices fell to approximately $5.77 per pound, marking the lowest point in nearly six weeks.
Upcoming seasonal holidays in China causing a pullback in manufacturing activity.

facts.fact_text: Copper fell to around $5.77 per pound on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Copper fell to around $5.77 per pound on Friday, hitting its lowest level in nearly six weeks

facts.fact_text: Stockpiles in LME warehouses across Asia are increasing.

evidences.evidence_text: Stockpiles in LME warehouses across Asia are also climbing

facts.fact_text: China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association projected refined copper output will rise about 5% in 2026.

evidences.evidence_text: China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association projected that refined copper output will rise about 5% in 2026, half the growth recorded in 2025.

claims.claim_text: The downward trend in copper prices could accelerate due to shipment diversions.
claims.author: Analysts

evidences.evidence_text: Analysts say the trend could accelerate as traders divert shipments from Africa to China to take advantage of temporary price gaps

claims.claim_text: Slowing demand from Chinese buyers is pressuring the market.

evidences.evidence_text: pressured by slowing demand from Chinese buyers and rising inventories

evidence.evidence_text: pressured by slowing demand from Chinese buyers and rising inventories
Stockpiles in LME warehouses across Asia are also climbing, further signaling softer demand.
Market sentiment was further weighed down after the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association projected that refined copper output will rise about 5% in 2026
